title: New Kassadin story
body: For what little my opinion is worth, I enjoyed it immensely. It had a feeling of weight to it. A vastness and a melancholy somewhere between despair and resolve. I really thoroughly liked the atmosphere and the wording and the background and, really, the whole thing. Kudos to everyone that worked on it and the art.

replies.body:
Thank you! I'm glad you liked it :-)

I'll be honest, it was inspired BY that magnificent piece of artwork. The moment I first saw that, last year, story ideas started whizzing around in my brain box...

It really is fantastic. It makes Kassadin out, in my opinion, to be an exhausted soul who wants more than anything to be reunited with his family again. But he can't, because he knows that as long as the Void threatens the land he cannot die. Or rather, give up. The story manages to perfectly describe the Void from the point of view of someone who was directly effected by it: an all consuming abyss whose very essence defies the world it seeks to devour. Kassadin comes off as tired, the kind of tired that only terrible loss and never-ending struggle can bring. And yet he keeps going, defying the Void. I like this story, I like it a lot.

You can find it in the Void page, it is in the art gallery.

I'm not not sure if Kai'sa is actually his daughter... It's hinted enough, but it's not really confirmed. It matters because Kassadin actually has the same problem that old Varus had... He isn't really connected to anyone. 

Like, how is he connected to other champions? Whats does he want after he beats the void? I feel like he needs some kind of connection to someone otherwise he feels more like a side character... But I still think the story was good, of course.

After...? Beats...?

Neither of those things are anywhere in his thoughts, right now. He just intends to go down swinging. There's something exceptionally powerful in someone who has literally nothing left to lose - Kassadin seems to be one of the few people in the world right now who even knows that Void-hearts exist, and they can be destroyed.

If only he found out that he actually had any kind of reason to keep on living, eh?

{{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}

Aha!  So Kai'sa really is his daughter! It's a super secret confirmation!!   Or.... He adopts? Gets a new partner when the plot moves forward? Ugggggh!!  Cuh mon, don't be like this!! {{sticker:sg-janna}}

I'm just going to say this - the best characters in any story are the ones who die...

Tragically.

And what if that reason was one for which to _keep_ fighting?

——

Kassadin gasped metallicly through his mask as the voice having called him emerged from the shadows.  Two huge growths stood on its shoulders, each with a mouth of crackling purple energy.  It was humanoid and, as its awful mask peeled back, indeed human.

“Who... are you?” he whispered.

“The Void Hunter,” the young woman behind the mask answered, “Who are you?”

“Whom the desert knows,” he said.

The hunter’s eyes opened wide for a moment, and she trailed off, reciting the Shuriman words,“Kas sai a dyn.”

Kassadin slowly floated toward her, gesturing with a gloved hand, “It is a meaning I have kept by my side for years, even in this place.”

She asked, stepping up to him, “Who were you, before you came here?”

“A merchant.  A tomb-robber.  A husband.  A father.”

They were only feet apart, now.  He could see her face clearly, and she could glimpse the eyes that lurked behind his goggles.  She extended her hand.  He took it.  

As a memory tugged at his mind, one came from her lips, “_My_ father.”

“It...” Kassadin stared at her.

“My name is Kai’Sa.  You are my father: Kassadin.”

As in the stories he had once told her as the fire crackled low by her bedside, their arms were around each other before they knew it.  For a moment that felt like an hour, father and daughter held one another, reunited.
